Background.graph: Given a causal graph with 7 nodes A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and 10 edges A->C, A->F, B->F, B->C, B->G, C->G, C->F, D->F, D->E, F->G.
Background.real_world_meaning: The real world meaning of each node is defined as follows: A represents qkya, B represents lzwc, C represents vjym, D represents qplw, E represents nlwd, F represents wkbo and G represents xkui.
Background.data_info: For those with lzwc being low, vjym being high and wkbo being high, the probability of xkui being low is 0.0864. For those with lzwc being high, vjym being high and wkbo being high, the probability of xkui being low is 0.0036.

Instruction: Consider the controlled direct effect (CDE) of lzwc on xkui.
Question: Conditioned on vjym being high and wkbo being high, if the lzwc had been low, would the xkui have been more likely to be low?

Reason.Step 1: Check whether there is an edge from treatment (B) to outcome (G). The edge B->G exists.
Reason.Step 2: Identification of the Causal Effect. P(G|do(B,C,F)) can be identified.
Reason.Step 3: Find a valid backdoor adjustment set: empty set.
Reason.Step 7: CDE=0.0828>0 so the answer is Yes.

given_info: Imagine a self-contained, hypothetical world with only the following conditions, and without any unmentioned factors or causal relationships: Qkya has a direct effect on vjym. Qkya has a direct effect on wkbo. Lzwc has a direct effect on wkbo. Lzwc has a direct effect on vjym. Lzwc has a direct effect on xkui. Vjym has a direct effect on xkui. Vjym has a direct effect on wkbo. Qplw has a direct effect on wkbo. Qplw has a direct effect on nlwd. Wkbo has a direct effect on xkui.
